sentence.text: Case 1 is a male infant born at 42.5 weeks' gestation to a healthy 29-year-old gravida 1, para 0-1 mother.
The mother reported no exposures to drugs or alcohol, but took antibiotics for a sinus infection at ∼32–34 weeks' gestation.
Pregnancy was complicated by the first-trimester finding of a presumed fraternal twin gestation with subsequent in utero demise.
A follow-up ultrasound 4 weeks later showed a singleton pregnancy.
Repeat ultrasonographic examinations at 20 and 30 weeks of gestation demonstrated no anomalies.
Labor was induced at 42½ weeks' gestation.
During active labor there was evidence of fetal distress, and concern was raised about a breech presentation (soft presenting body part on vaginal exam).
A flat-plate radiograph obtained in the delivery room confirmed a vertex presentation.
The baby then developed fetal distress with evidence of placental abruption and was delivered under general anesthesia by cesarean section with a birth weight of 7 lb 4 oz.
The infant was in the vertex position.
Shortly after birth he was found to have nearly complete absence of a mineralized calvaria.
Screening laboratory test results for levels of alkaline phosphatase, magnesium, free thyroxine (T4), thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), and calcium were all within normal limits.

At 4 days of age a craniofacial examination revealed hypertelorism, a depressed nasal bridge, and, most notably, a complete absence of the parietal bones and severely hypoplasic frontal, temporal, and occipital bones.
The gyri and sulci of the cortex were easily palpated through the scalp.
The findings of the remainder of the examination were normal.
The infant was vigorous and was fitted for a soft-form helmet and observed for secondary calvarial growth.
Radiographic imaging included 2- and 3-dimensional (3D) computed tomography (CT) scans that documented complete absence of the parietal bones and zygomatic arch clefts at birth (Fig. 1).
Subsequent imaging studies showed a unilateral pseudarthrosis of the clavicle and decreased mineralization of the pubic symphysis (not shown).
By 9 months of age, a repeat CT scan showed new bone formation in the parietal area.
By 14 months of age, he had developed mild brachycephaly, progressive hypertelorism, and an increased anterior-posterior diameter of the thorax.
His hearing is normal, and he has met all of his developmental milestones.
His family history revealed a father, 2 paternal uncles, and a paternal first cousin who had short stature and delayed closure of the anterior fontanel.
